description: On June 26, the upper house of the Tajikistan Parliament approved controversial changes to the Code of Administrative Offenses, which provide for a fine for knowingly false information about the coronavirus pandemic in the media and social networks.

description: Tajikistan asks mosques "to suspend public gatherings, including Friday prayers but excluding burial rites" on March 4. Additionally, they are "cancelling traditional public festivities related to the Nowruz holiday, or Persian New Year, celebrated from March 21-25." The Committee for Religion and the Ordering of Traditions and Rites of Tajikistan has allowed public prayer in mosques of the country since March 20.

In Tajikistan "The Dushanbe city municipality said that 'all mass festivities dedicated to the Day of the Capital will be suspended in Dushanbe with the aim of preventing the spread of the coronavirus [Covid-19] and protecting people's health." This Day of the Capital is on April 18.

Tajikistan asks mosques "to suspend public gatherings, including Friday prayers but excluding burial rites" on March 4. Additionally, they are "cancelling traditional public festivities related to the Nowruz holiday, or Persian New Year, celebrated from March 21-25."
On March 4, this restriction was cancelled, but on April 18 all mosques were closed again to prevent mass prayers due to upcoming Ramadan.
In Tajikistan all visits to inmates held in prisons and detention centers had been suspended as of March 31 as a measure of social distancing.
